elements.content: <ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">The 3-D network compounds [NiCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(pip)] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>I<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(pip)] (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) have been reported, which constructed from 1-D zigzag NiCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> chains and 1-D merlon-like CuI double chains bridged by pip molecules, respectively. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows ferromagnetic property, while compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> possesses fluorescent property with an emission at 567<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract
The 3-D network compounds [NiCl2(pip)] (1) and [Cu2I2(pip)] (2) have been reported, which constructed from 1-D zigzag NiCl2 chains and 1-D merlon-like CuI double chains bridged by pip molecules, respectively. Compound 1 shows ferromagnetic property, while compound 2 possesses fluorescent property with an emission at 567nm.

elements.content:
<ce:figure>
<ce:link locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>

<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">By the simple hydro/solvothermal reaction, two new 3-D metal–halo cluster polymers, [NiCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(pip)] (pip<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>piperazine) (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>I<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(pip)] (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) were obtained and characterized by IR spectroscopy, CHN analysis and TG analysis. Single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that, the 3-D network of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are constructed from the 1-D zigzag NiCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> chains and the 1-D castellated Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>I<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> chains bridged by pip molecules respectively. The μ<ce:inf loc="post">eff</ce:inf> versus <ce:italic>T</ce:italic> curve indicates that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is ferromagnetic when <ce:italic>T</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>><ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>14<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. The photoluminscent spectrum shows that compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> possesses the fluorescent property with a broad emission peak at 567<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm upon excision at 397<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract
By the simple hydro/solvothermal reaction, two new 3-D metal–halo cluster polymers, [NiCl2(pip)] (pip=piperazine) (1) and [Cu2I2(pip)] (2) were obtained and characterized by IR spectroscopy, CHN analysis and TG analysis. Single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that, the 3-D network of compounds 1 and 2 are constructed from the 1-D zigzag NiCl2 chains and the 1-D castellated Cu2I2 chains bridged by pip molecules respectively. The μeff versus T curve indicates that compound 1 is ferromagnetic when T
>14K. The photoluminscent spectrum shows that compound 2 possesses the fluorescent property with a broad emission peak at 567nm upon excision at 397nm.

other properties: fluorescent property with a broad emission peak at 567 nm upon excision at 397 nm

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">In the past decade, the study on the design and synthesis of novel cluster polymers achieved considerable attention due to the structural unpredictability (i.e., which cluster will form and what is the linking mode between the clusters and organic moieties) and potential functional properties in some fields as optics (containing groups IB, IIB or rare-earth metal), electrochemistry based on the metals with many oxidation states, catalysis (poly-acid, zeolite or zeolite-like materials), electrical conductivity (containing group IVA metal) and magnetism . As far as the construction of cluster polymers is concerned, on the one hand, the inorganic salts being prone to form the clusters, such as oxides, halides or sulfides are usually used as the inorganic precursors to form inorganic subunits (SUs) . On the other hand, the literature show that three types of bridges can extend the inorganic SUs into poly-nuclear or high-dimensional (D) cluster polymers: (i) inorganic bridge. With various organic ammines as guest species or organic templating agents, the SUs interact with each other through covalent M–O (X or S) bonds (or through sharing the corner, edge or/and face) between the SUs, producing new polymeric clusters. This is the basic constructing conception of zeolite and zeolite-like materials . (ii) Organic bridge, the most common method. Up to now, lots of bridging organic ligands with N/O/S donors have been chosen to extend the SUs into the 1-D, 2-D, 3-D cluster polymers via covalent interactions or a combination of covalent and non-covalent interactions . (iii) Metal complex bridge. This strategy has been extensively adopted when preparing high-D poly-acids . Some recent reports show that it is being extended to the construction of metal–halo cluster polymers .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction
In the past decade, the study on the design and synthesis of novel cluster polymers achieved considerable attention due to the structural unpredictability (i.e., which cluster will form and what is the linking mode between the clusters and organic moieties) and potential functional properties in some fields as optics (containing groups IB, IIB or rare-earth metal), electrochemistry based on the metals with many oxidation states, catalysis (poly-acid, zeolite or zeolite-like materials), electrical conductivity (containing group IVA metal) and magnetism . As far as the construction of cluster polymers is concerned, on the one hand, the inorganic salts being prone to form the clusters, such as oxides, halides or sulfides are usually used as the inorganic precursors to form inorganic subunits (SUs) . On the other hand, the literature show that three types of bridges can extend the inorganic SUs into poly-nuclear or high-dimensional (D) cluster polymers: (i) inorganic bridge. With various organic ammines as guest species or organic templating agents, the SUs interact with each other through covalent M–O (X or S) bonds (or through sharing the corner, edge or/and face) between the SUs, producing new polymeric clusters. This is the basic constructing conception of zeolite and zeolite-like materials . (ii) Organic bridge, the most common method. Up to now, lots of bridging organic ligands with N/O/S donors have been chosen to extend the SUs into the 1-D, 2-D, 3-D cluster polymers via covalent interactions or a combination of covalent and non-covalent interactions . (iii) Metal complex bridge. This strategy has been extensively adopted when preparing high-D poly-acids . Some recent reports show that it is being extended to the construction of metal–halo cluster polymers .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Since 2001, one of the investigations in our group is focused on the synthesis and property of metal–halo cluster polymers based on these three construction strategies stated above. Some interesting compounds such as the 3-D [CuX<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(1,4-btzb)] [X<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Cl<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, Br<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>; 1,4-btzb<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,4-bis(tetrazol-1-yl)butane] , 2-D [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(phen)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>][Cu<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>Br<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>] (phen<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,10-phenanthroline)  and decanuclear [Ni(phen)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>[Cu<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>HI<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf>]  have been obtained. Herein, we report the syntheses and characterization of two new 3-D metal–halo cluster polymers: [NiCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(pip)] <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>I<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(pip)] <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> obtained by the simple hydro/solvothermal technique.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Since 2001, one of the investigations in our group is focused on the synthesis and property of metal–halo cluster polymers based on these three construction strategies stated above. Some interesting compounds such as the 3-D [CuX2(1,4-btzb)] [X−
=Cl−, Br−; 1,4-btzb=1,4-bis(tetrazol-1-yl)butane] , 2-D [Cu4(OH)4(phen)4][Cu8Br12] (phen=1,10-phenanthroline)  and decanuclear [Ni(phen)3]2[Cu10HI15]  have been obtained. Herein, we report the syntheses and characterization of two new 3-D metal–halo cluster polymers: [NiCl2(pip)] 1 and [Cu2I2(pip)] 2 obtained by the simple hydro/solvothermal technique.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental
Materials and general methods
The chemicals used to prepare the title compounds include NiCl2
·6H2O, CuI, KI, pip·6H2O, H2C2O4
·2H2O, succinic acid and ethanol without further purification. The synthesis was carried out in 30mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessels under autogenous pressure. Elemental (CHN) analysis was performed with a Perkin–Elmer 2400LS II elemental analyzer. Infrared (IR) spectrum was recorded with a Perkin–Elmer Spectrum 1 spectrophotometer in the 4000–400cm−1 region using a powdered sample on a KBr plate.

elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of complex

[NiCl2(pip)] (1). To a 16mL ethanol, NiCl2
·6H2O (0.24g, 1mmol), pip·6H2O (0.19g, 1mmol) and succinic acid (0.12g, 1mmol) were added in succession. After being stirred for 4h, the mixture (pH=6) was sealed in a 30mL Teflon-lined autoclave, and then heated in an oven at 170°C. After 3 days, green needle crystals were obtained, being washed with ethanol and dried in ambient temperature. Yield: ca. 30% based on Ni. IR (cm−1): 3206 s, 2976 w, 2942 w, 1447 w, 1421 m, 1136 s, 1085 w, 1027 m, 1002 w, 855 s, 664 w, 397 w. Anal. Calc. for C4H10N2NiCl2: C, 22.27; H, 4.67; N, 12.98. Found: C, 22.35; H, 4.59; N, 12.90%.

<ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Structural description</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">So far, the report on nickel–halo coordination polymer with the bridging N-donor ligand is rather rare. The classical cases are compounds [NiX<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4,4′-bpy)] (X<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Cl<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, Br<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>; bpy<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>bipyridine) , which show a 2-D layered topology consisting of the 1-D NiX<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> chains bridged by 4,4′-bpy ligands.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion
Structural description
So far, the report on nickel–halo coordination polymer with the bridging N-donor ligand is rather rare. The classical cases are compounds [NiX2(4,4′-bpy)] (X−
=Cl−, Br−; bpy=bipyridine) , which show a 2-D layered topology consisting of the 1-D NiX2 chains bridged by 4,4′-bpy ligands.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Using the pip in place of the 4,4′-bpy, the title 3-D compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> with a different topology from the former was synthesized. With the pip, NiCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O forms a 1-D chained SU. The Ni(II) center with an octahedral geometry is coordinated by four Cl<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ions and two N atoms from the different pip. The Ni–N bond length [2.118(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å] and the average Ni-Cl bond length [2.475<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å] are similar to those found in reported [NiCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4,4′-bpy)] . Through the μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Cl bridges, all of the Ni(II) centers are linked into a zigzag chain, which can be described as an infinite extension of edge-shared NiCl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> octahedra. The Ni(pip)<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> unit adopts a <ce:italic>cis</ce:italic>-type arrangement. It is noticeable that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> displays the different porous shapes in different directions. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>, in [100] direction, it takes on a trigonal channel with base 6.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and height 6.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. While in [0<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>1] direction, it displays a square hydrophobic channel with the size of 7.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>7.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Using the pip in place of the 4,4′-bpy, the title 3-D compound 1 with a different topology from the former was synthesized. With the pip, NiCl2
·6H2O forms a 1-D chained SU. The Ni(II) center with an octahedral geometry is coordinated by four Cl− ions and two N atoms from the different pip. The Ni–N bond length [2.118(2)Å] and the average Ni-Cl bond length [2.475Å] are similar to those found in reported [NiCl2(4,4′-bpy)] . Through the μ2-Cl bridges, all of the Ni(II) centers are linked into a zigzag chain, which can be described as an infinite extension of edge-shared NiCl4N2 octahedra. The Ni(pip)2+ unit adopts a cis-type arrangement. It is noticeable that compound 1 displays the different porous shapes in different directions. As shown in 
, in [100] direction, it takes on a trigonal channel with base 6.3Å and height 6.6Å. While in [001] direction, it displays a square hydrophobic channel with the size of 7.9×7.9Å2.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Comparing the topology of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> with one of [NiX<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4,4′-bpy)], we can find that the different organic ligands lead to the different topologies. The reason is that NiL<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> unit adopts the different geometric configuration duing to the different bulk of organic ligand. In compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, Ni(pip)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> is <ce:italic>cis</ce:italic>-pattern, which helps to extend NiCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> chains into a 3-D network, while in [NiX<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4,4′-bpy)], Ni(4,4′-bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> is <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic>-pattern. In addition, the different NiL<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> type has an effect on NiX<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> chain arrangement: zigzag type in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>; linear-type in [NiX<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4,4′-bpy)].</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Comparing the topology of 1 with one of [NiX2(4,4′-bpy)], we can find that the different organic ligands lead to the different topologies. The reason is that NiL2
2+ unit adopts the different geometric configuration duing to the different bulk of organic ligand. In compound 1, Ni(pip)2
2+ is cis-pattern, which helps to extend NiCl2 chains into a 3-D network, while in [NiX2(4,4′-bpy)], Ni(4,4′-bpy)2
2+ is trans-pattern. In addition, the different NiL2
2+ type has an effect on NiX2 chain arrangement: zigzag type in 1; linear-type in [NiX2(4,4′-bpy)].

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Compared with the Ni(II), the structure of copper–halo clusters is richer due to the diversity of coordination geometry of Cu(I). With bridging N-donor ligands, CuX can form various neutral oligomeric and polymeric clusters, namely so-called SUs. The most reports are rhombic dimer, cubane tetramer, zigzag-type and staircase chains . Further, these SUs are extended by organic bridges into the 1-D, 2-D or 3-D networks. It was reported that the size of organic ligands determines the mode of the SUs. In general, the bulky ligands as 4,4′-bpy favor the formation of discrete SUs, whereas the small ones favor the polymeric SUs. In compound [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Br<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tri)] (tri<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,3,5-triazine) , the castellated CuI single chain was reported, while in compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, a new castellated CuI double chain was observed in reaction with the pip.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Compared with the Ni(II), the structure of copper–halo clusters is richer due to the diversity of coordination geometry of Cu(I). With bridging N-donor ligands, CuX can form various neutral oligomeric and polymeric clusters, namely so-called SUs. The most reports are rhombic dimer, cubane tetramer, zigzag-type and staircase chains . Further, these SUs are extended by organic bridges into the 1-D, 2-D or 3-D networks. It was reported that the size of organic ligands determines the mode of the SUs. In general, the bulky ligands as 4,4′-bpy favor the formation of discrete SUs, whereas the small ones favor the polymeric SUs. In compound [Cu2Br2(tri)] (tri=1,3,5-triazine) , the castellated CuI single chain was reported, while in compound 2, a new castellated CuI double chain was observed in reaction with the pip.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">X-ray analysis reveals that the structure of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> features a new 3-D framework constructed from the 1-D Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>I<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> chains bridged by the pip molecules. With the pip, CuI forms a 1-D castellated Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>I<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> chain as shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>a. The Cu(I) ion adopts a distorted tetrahedral geometry [the angles around Cu(I) ion being from 103.52(9) to 117.373(19)°] and is coordinated by three equivalent I<ce:sup loc="post">-</ce:sup> ions and one N atom from the pip. The Cu–I bond lengths, ranging from 2.6569(8) to 2.6876(8)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, are comparable with those observed in the reported similar compounds . The distances of Cu⋯Cu [2.7294(10)–2.7707(11)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å] are less than twice the van der Waals radius of the Cu (2.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), which implies that there exist the weaker Cu⋯Cu interactions within the inorganic chains. The I<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ions with a trigonal pyramidal geometry link the tetrahedral Cu(I) to form a castellated Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>I<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> chain, which is obviously different from the known zigzag chain and the staircase chain. Next, the pip molecules protrude out from the inorganic chains, bridging them into a 3-D framework with the 1-D channels in different directions. In [1<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0] direction, the channel is rectangular with the size of 2.7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>9.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> (see b), while in [0<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>1] direction the channel is a diamondoid structure with the size of 7.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>13.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> (see c).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray analysis reveals that the structure of compound 2 features a new 3-D framework constructed from the 1-D Cu2I2 chains bridged by the pip molecules. With the pip, CuI forms a 1-D castellated Cu2I2 chain as shown in 
a. The Cu(I) ion adopts a distorted tetrahedral geometry [the angles around Cu(I) ion being from 103.52(9) to 117.373(19)°] and is coordinated by three equivalent I- ions and one N atom from the pip. The Cu–I bond lengths, ranging from 2.6569(8) to 2.6876(8)Å, are comparable with those observed in the reported similar compounds . The distances of Cu⋯Cu [2.7294(10)–2.7707(11)Å] are less than twice the van der Waals radius of the Cu (2.8Å), which implies that there exist the weaker Cu⋯Cu interactions within the inorganic chains. The I− ions with a trigonal pyramidal geometry link the tetrahedral Cu(I) to form a castellated Cu2I2 chain, which is obviously different from the known zigzag chain and the staircase chain. Next, the pip molecules protrude out from the inorganic chains, bridging them into a 3-D framework with the 1-D channels in different directions. In [100] direction, the channel is rectangular with the size of 2.7×9.0Å2 (see b), while in [001] direction the channel is a diamondoid structure with the size of 7.5×13.9Å2 (see c).

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Based on the title compounds and the documents, it is easy to find that the structure of copper(I)–halo cluster is richer than that of nickel–halo cluster. Perhaps it is due to the flexibility of the metal ion. Generally, the X<ce:sup loc="post">-</ce:sup> ion has a tendency to exhibit the multi-types of bridging-modes with the flexible metal. For example, in the reported Cu(I)–X cluster compounds, the X<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ions take on the μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-, μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-, μ<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>- and μ<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>-bridging modes with linear, trigonal pyramidal, tetrahedral, planar rectangular, tetragonal pyramidal, pentagonal pyramidal and umbrella-like (μ<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>-) geometric configurations .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Based on the title compounds and the documents, it is easy to find that the structure of copper(I)–halo cluster is richer than that of nickel–halo cluster. Perhaps it is due to the flexibility of the metal ion. Generally, the X- ion has a tendency to exhibit the multi-types of bridging-modes with the flexible metal. For example, in the reported Cu(I)–X cluster compounds, the X− ions take on the μ2-, μ3-, μ4- and μ5-bridging modes with linear, trigonal pyramidal, tetrahedral, planar rectangular, tetragonal pyramidal, pentagonal pyramidal and umbrella-like (μ4-) geometric configurations .

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Synthetic analysis</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">It deserves to note that the pH level of the system plays a key role in the course of crystal growth. The optimal pH values are 6 for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and 9 for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, respectively. The reasonable explanation may be: (i) in a acid condition, the Cu<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> ion will be disproportionated to the Cu<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ion and the Cu metal. (ii) In a basic condition, the Ni<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ion exists in the Ni(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> form.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthetic analysis
It deserves to note that the pH level of the system plays a key role in the course of crystal growth. The optimal pH values are 6 for 1 and 9 for 2, respectively. The reasonable explanation may be: (i) in a acid condition, the Cu+ ion will be disproportionated to the Cu2+ ion and the Cu metal. (ii) In a basic condition, the Ni2+ ion exists in the Ni(OH)2 form.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">As literature reported, the bridging organic acid can be used as one of the precursors when preparing hybrid metal–halo coordination polymers. Sometimes, organic acid appeared in the final product as the reported Na[Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O  and Na<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>[Cd<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>X] (X<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Cl<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, Br<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>; C<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>succinate) . Sometimes, organic acid didn’t appear in the final product. Just as Rao has ever mentioned, the real role of organic acids is still unclear, but the target products can’t be obtained without them .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
As literature reported, the bridging organic acid can be used as one of the precursors when preparing hybrid metal–halo coordination polymers. Sometimes, organic acid appeared in the final product as the reported Na[Cd2Cl4(C2O4)0.5]·4H2O  and Na3[Cd5(C4H4O4)6X] (X−
=Cl−, Br−; C4H4O4
=succinate) . Sometimes, organic acid didn’t appear in the final product. Just as Rao has ever mentioned, the real role of organic acids is still unclear, but the target products can’t be obtained without them .

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>TG analysis</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Thermogravimetric (TG) behavior was investigated on a SHIMADZU DTG-60 instrument in a temperature range of 25–800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C with a heating rate of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> in air. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>, compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits one-step continuous weight-loss in the temperature range of 310–575<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. The final residue is proved to be NiO (calc.: 34.62%; found: 33.15%), which suggests that the pip molecule and the Cl<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ion released simultaneously, meanwhile, the Ni(II) ion combined with the O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> to form the NiO. Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> underwent two steps of the weight loss. The first step from 210<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C to 440<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C should correspond to the loss of the pip, meanwhile, part Cu(I) transformed into CuO (calc.: 18.43%; found: 12.67%). The second stage should correspond to the sublimation of the I<ce:sup loc="post">-</ce:sup> ion and the oxidation of the residual Cu(I) (calc.: 54%; found: 51%).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
TG analysis
Thermogravimetric (TG) behavior was investigated on a SHIMADZU DTG-60 instrument in a temperature range of 25–800°C with a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1 in air. As shown in 
, compound 1 exhibits one-step continuous weight-loss in the temperature range of 310–575°C. The final residue is proved to be NiO (calc.: 34.62%; found: 33.15%), which suggests that the pip molecule and the Cl− ion released simultaneously, meanwhile, the Ni(II) ion combined with the O2 to form the NiO. Compound 2 underwent two steps of the weight loss. The first step from 210°C to 440°C should correspond to the loss of the pip, meanwhile, part Cu(I) transformed into CuO (calc.: 18.43%; found: 12.67%). The second stage should correspond to the sublimation of the I- ion and the oxidation of the residual Cu(I) (calc.: 54%; found: 51%).

Upon cooling down, μ<ce:inf loc="post">eff</ce:inf> increases continuously up to a maximum of 4.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μ<ce:inf loc="post">B</ce:inf> at 14<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, then drops rapidly down to a value of 1.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μ<ce:inf loc="post">B</ce:inf> at 2 K. The 1/<ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>><ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K [see  (right)], being well fitted by using the Curie Weiss law with <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.014<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>emu<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, and <ce:italic>θ</ce:italic>

On the other hand, zero-field splitting is known to occur for Ni(II) ions, and for isolated ions may induce either an increase or a decrease of μ<ce:inf loc="post">eff</ce:inf> value at rather low temperature due to the site distortion of metal ion. Based on both stated above, the observed behavior is thus characteristic of the occurrence of ferromagnetic interactions within the NiCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> chains due to a plus <ce:italic>θ</ce:italic> value, whereas the drop below 14<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K can be related to antiferromagnetic coupling between the chains as well as the effect of zero-field splitting. Magnetic property
Magnetic susceptibility data were determined on the basis of a 10.3mg sample over the temperature of 2–300K at a magnetic field of 1 kG on a Quantum Design MPMS-7 SQUID magnetometer. The μeff versus T plot is shown in 
 (left) [μeff
=2.83 (χ
M
T)1/2]. The experimental μeff value at 300 K is 3.11μB, comparable with the theoretically expected value of 2.83μB for a d8 Ni(II) ion with an octahedral geometry. Upon cooling down, μeff increases continuously up to a maximum of 4.8μB at 14K, then drops rapidly down to a value of 1.4μB at 2 K. The 1/χ
M versus T curve is close to be linear when T
>150K [see  (right)], being well fitted by using the Curie Weiss law with C
=1.014emuKmol−1, and θ
=53.97K. On the other hand, zero-field splitting is known to occur for Ni(II) ions, and for isolated ions may induce either an increase or a decrease of μeff value at rather low temperature due to the site distortion of metal ion. Based on both stated above, the observed behavior is thus characteristic of the occurrence of ferromagnetic interactions within the NiCl2 chains due to a plus θ value, whereas the drop below 14K can be related to antiferromagnetic coupling between the chains as well as the effect of zero-field splitting. A 1-D chain model was used to fit the magnetic data of compound 1, unluckily no ideal result was obtained .

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Photoluminescent property</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The photoluminescent spectrum of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was measured on a LS 55 florescence/phosphorescence in the solid state at room temperature. As displayed in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig5"></ce:float-anchor>, the emission spectrum of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows a strong band at 567<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm with a shoulder at 593<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm when excited at 397<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. The emission may be from a triplet “cluster centered” (<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>CC<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup>) excited state, which should be assigned to a combination of iodide to copper charge transfer (IMCT<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup>) and “metal cluster centered” [(<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>MCC<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup>), d<ce:inf loc="post">Cu</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>(s,p)<ce:inf loc="post">Cu</ce:inf>] transition. The weak Cu⋯Cu interactions with an average distance of 2.75<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å within the Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>I<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> chain, as literature reported, will be responsible for a <ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>MCC<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup> excited solid .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescent property
The photoluminescent spectrum of compound 2 was measured on a LS 55 florescence/phosphorescence in the solid state at room temperature. As displayed in 
, the emission spectrum of compound 2 shows a strong band at 567nm with a shoulder at 593nm when excited at 397nm. The emission may be from a triplet “cluster centered” (3CC∗) excited state, which should be assigned to a combination of iodide to copper charge transfer (IMCT∗) and “metal cluster centered” [(3MCC∗), dCu
→(s,p)Cu] transition. The weak Cu⋯Cu interactions with an average distance of 2.75Å within the Cu2I2 chain, as literature reported, will be responsible for a 3MCC∗ excited solid .

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Two new metal–halo cluster polymers based on the pip ligand have been obtained, which show the 3-D network structures comprising the 1-D zigzag NiCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> SUs and the 1-D castellated Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>I<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> SUs, respectively. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> possesses the ferromagnetism, whereas compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> displays the fluorescence due to the existence of the weaker Cu⋯Cu interaction. The interrelated work is still going on, aiming at getting more compounds and exploring the relationship between the structure and the property.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion
Two new metal–halo cluster polymers based on the pip ligand have been obtained, which show the 3-D network structures comprising the 1-D zigzag NiCl2 SUs and the 1-D castellated Cu2I2 SUs, respectively. Compound 1 possesses the ferromagnetism, whereas compound 2 displays the fluorescence due to the existence of the weaker Cu⋯Cu interaction. The interrelated work is still going on, aiming at getting more compounds and exploring the relationship between the structure and the property.
